title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: Mediation analysis statistical method used explore mechanisms independent variable influences dependent variable one intermediary variables, known mediators. process involves assessing indirect, direct, total effects within defined statistical framework. primary goal mediation analysis test mediation hypothesis, posits effect independent variable dependent variable partially fully mediated intermediate variables. examining pathways, researchers can gain deeper understanding causal relationships among variables. Mediation analysis particularly valuable refining interventions enhance effectiveness clinical trials observational studies, helps identify key intervention targets elucidate mechanisms underlying complex diseases.

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: HIMA package provides robust tools estimating testing high-dimensional mediation effects, specifically designed modern omic data, including epigenetics, transcriptomics, microbiomics. supports high-dimensional mediation analysis across continuous, binary, survival outcomes, specialized methods tailored compositional microbiome data quantile mediation analysis. core package hima function, flexible powerful wrapper integrates various high-dimensional mediation analysis methods effect estimation hypothesis testing. hima function automatically selects suitable analytical approach based outcome mediator data type, streamlining complex workflows reducing user burden. hima designed extensibility mind, allowing seamless integration future features methods. ensures consistent, user-friendly interface staying adaptable evolving analytical needs.

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: hima function provides flexible user-friendly interface performing high-dimensional mediation analysis. supports variety analysis methods tailored continuous, binary, survival, compositional data. overview hima function key parameters:

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: use hima function, ensure data prepared according following guidelines:
code: hima(   formula,          # The model formula specifying outcome, exposure, and covariates   data.pheno,       # Data frame with outcome, exposure, and covariates   data.M,           # Data frame or matrix of high-dimensional mediators   mediator.type,    # Type of mediators: "gaussian", "negbin", or "compositional"   penalty = "DBlasso",  # Penalty method: "DBlasso", "MCP", "SCAD", or "lasso"   quantile = FALSE, # Use quantile mediation analysis (default: FALSE)   efficient = FALSE,# Use efficient mediation analysis (default: FALSE)   scale = TRUE,     # Scale data (default: TRUE)   sigcut = 0.05,    # Significance cutoff for mediator selection   contrast = NULL,  # Named list of contrasts for factor covariates   subset = NULL,    # Optional subset of observations   verbose = FALSE   # Display progress messages (default: FALSE) )

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: Define model formula specify relationship Outcome, Exposure, Covariate(s). Ensure following: General Form: Use format Outcome ~ Exposure + Covariate(s). Note Exposure variable represents exposure interest (e.g., “Treatment” demo examples) listed first independent variable formula. Covariate(s) optional. Interaction Terms: Optionally include interaction terms required analysis. Survival Data: survival analysis, use format Surv(time, event) ~ Exposure + Covariate(s). See data examples SurvivalData$PhenoData details.

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: data.pheno object data.frame matrix containing phenotype information analysis (without missing values). Key requirements include: Rows: Represent samples. Columns: Include variables outcome, treatment, optional covariate(s). Formula Consistency: Ensure variables specified formula argument (e.g., Outcome, Treatment, Covariate(s)) present data.pheno.

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: data.M object data.frame matrix containing high-dimensional mediators (without missing values). Key requirements include: Rows: Represent samples, aligned rows data.pheno. Columns: Represent mediators (e.g., CpGs, genes, molecular features). Mediator Type: Specify type mediators mediator.type argument. Supported types include: "gaussian" continuous mediators (default, e.g., DNA methylation data). "negbin" count data (e.g., transcriptomic data). "compositional" microbiome compositional data.

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: real-world data analysis scenarios, scale typically set TRUE, ensuring exposure (variable interest), mediators, covariate(s) (included) standardized mean zero variance one. scaling applied Outcome. However, data already pre-standardized—simulation studies using demo dataset-scale set FALSE prevent introducing biases altering original data structure. applying HIMA simulated data, scale set TRUE, imperative preprocess mediators scaling mean zero variance one prior generating outcome variables.

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
code: library(HIMA)

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: analyzing continuous normally distributed outcomes mediators, can use following code snippet: penaly can set DBlasso may help detect mediators weaker signals.
code: data(ContinuousOutcome) hima_continuous.fit <- hima(   Outcome ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = ContinuousOutcome$PhenoData,   data.M = ContinuousOutcome$Mediator,   mediator.type = "gaussian",   penalty = "MCP",   scale = FALSE # Demo data is already standardized ) summary(hima_continuous.fit, desc=TRUE)  # `desc = TRUE` option to show the description of the output results

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: continuous normally distributed mediators outcomes, efficient HIMA method can activated efficient = TRUE option (penalty MCP best results). method may also provide greater statistical power detect mediators weaker signals. recommended try different penalty options efficient option find best one data.
code: hima_efficient.fit <- hima(   Outcome ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = ContinuousOutcome$PhenoData,   data.M = ContinuousOutcome$Mediator,   mediator.type = "gaussian",   efficient = TRUE,   penalty = "lasso",   scale = FALSE # Demo data is already standardized ) summary(hima_efficient.fit, desc=TRUE)  # Note that the efficient HIMA is controlling FDR

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: package can handle binary outcomes based logistic regression:
code: data(BinaryOutcome) hima_binary.fit <- hima(   Disease ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = BinaryOutcome$PhenoData,   data.M = BinaryOutcome$Mediator,   mediator.type = "gaussian",   penalty = "MCP",   scale = FALSE # Demo data is already standardized ) summary(hima_binary.fit)

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: survival data, HIMA incorporates Cox proportional hazards approach. example survival outcome analysis using HIMA:
code: data(SurvivalData) hima_survival.fit <- hima(   Surv(Time, Status) ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = SurvivalData$PhenoData,   data.M = SurvivalData$Mediator,   mediator.type = "gaussian",   penalty = "DBlasso",   scale = FALSE # Demo data is already standardized ) summary(hima_survival.fit)

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: compositional microbiome data, HIMA employs isometric Log-Ratio transformations. example microbiome mediation analysis using HIMA:
code: data(MicrobiomeData) hima_microbiome.fit <- hima(   Outcome ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = MicrobiomeData$PhenoData,   data.M = MicrobiomeData$Mediator,   mediator.type = "compositional",   penalty = "DBlasso" ) summary(hima_microbiome.fit)

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: Perform quantile mediation analysis using quantile = TRUE option specify tau desired quantile(s):
code: data(QuantileData) hima_quantile.fit <- hima(   Outcome ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = QuantileData$PhenoData,   data.M = QuantileData$Mediator,   mediator.type = "gaussian",   quantile = TRUE,   penalty = "MCP",   tau = c(0.3, 0.5, 0.7),   scale = FALSE # Demo data is already standardized ) summary(hima_quantile.fit)

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis
text: HIMA now available R CRAN repository install GitHub package “qvalue” found, please first install “qvalue” package Bioconductor: https://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/qvalue.html
code: ## Install HIMA install.packages("HIMA") ## Install HIMA from GitHub library(devtools) install_github("yinanzheng/HIMA") if (!require("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager") BiocManager::install("qvalue")

what: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis for 'Omic' Data — HIMA-package
title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis for 'Omic' Data — HIMA-package
text: HIMA R package estimating testing high-dimensional mediation effects omic studies. HIMA can perform high-dimensional mediation analysis wide range omic data types potential mediators, including epigenetics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics, microbiomics. HIMA can also handle survival data mediation analysis perform quantile mediation analysis.

title: High-Dimensional Mediation Analysis for 'Omic' Data — HIMA-package
text: # package "qvalue" found installation, please first install "qvalue" package # Bioconductor: https://www.bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/qvalue.html

text: Yinan Zheng y-zheng@northwestern.edu, Haixiang Zhang haixiang.zhang@tju.edu.cn, Lei liu (Contact) lei.liu@wustl.edu Maintainer: Yinan Zheng y-zheng@northwestern.edu

title: High-dimensional Mediation Analysis — hima
text: hima wrapper function designed perform various HIMA methods estimating testing high-dimensional mediation effects. hima can automatically select appropriate HIMA method based outcome mediator data type.

title: High-dimensional Mediation Analysis — hima
code: hima(   formula,   data.pheno,   data.M,   mediator.type = c("gaussian", "negbin", "compositional"),   penalty = c("DBlasso", "MCP", "SCAD", "lasso"),   quantile = FALSE,   efficient = FALSE,   scale = TRUE,   sigcut = 0.05,   contrast = NULL,   subset = NULL,   verbose = FALSE,   ... )

title: High-dimensional Mediation Analysis — hima
text: formula object class formula representing overall effect model fitted, specified outcome ~ exposure + covariates. "exposure" variable (variable interest) must listed first right-hand side formula. data.pheno data frame containing exposure, outcome, covariates specified formula. Variable names data.pheno must match formula. scale = TRUE, exposure covariates scaled (outcome retains original scale). data.M data.frame matrix high-dimensional mediators, rows representing samples columns representing mediator variables. scale = TRUE, data.M scaled. mediator.type character string indicating data type high-dimensional mediators (data.M). Options : 'gaussian' (default): continuous mediators. 'negbin': count data mediators modeled using negative binomial distribution (e.g., RNA-seq data). 'compositional': compositional data mediators (e.g., microbiome data). penalty character string specifying penalty method apply model. Options : 'DBlasso': De-biased LASSO (default). 'MCP': Minimax Concave Penalty. 'SCAD': Smoothly Clipped Absolute Deviation. 'lasso': Least Absolute Shrinkage Selection Operator. Note: Survival HIMA microbiome HIMA can performed 'DBlasso'. Quantile HIMA efficient HIMA use 'DBlasso'; always apply 'MCP'. quantile logical. Indicates whether use quantile HIMA (hima_quantile). Default FALSE. Applicable classic HIMA continuous outcome mediator.type = 'gaussian'. TRUE, specify desired quantile(s) using tau parameter; otherwise, default tau = 0.5 (.e., median) used. efficient logical. Indicates whether use efficient HIMA (hima_efficient). Default FALSE. Applicable classic HIMA continuous outcome mediator.type = 'gaussian'. scale logical. Determines whether function scales data (exposure, mediators, covariates). Default TRUE. Note: simulation studies, set scale = FALSE avoid estimate compression (.e., shrinkage estimates toward zero due scaling). sigcut numeric. significance cutoff selecting mediators. Default 0.05. contrast named list contrasts applied factor variables covariates (variable interest). subset optional vector specifying subset observations use analysis. verbose logical. Determines whether function displays progress messages. Default FALSE. ... reserved passing parameter (future use).

title: High-dimensional Mediation Analysis — hima
text: data.frame containing mediation testing results selected mediators. ID: Mediator ID/name. alpha: Coefficient estimates exposure (X) –> mediators (M) (adjusted covariates). beta: Coefficient estimates mediators (M) –> outcome (Y) (adjusted covariates exposure). alpha*beta: estimated indirect (mediation) effect exposure outcome mediator. Relative Importance: proportion mediator's mediation effect relative sum absolute mediation effects significant mediators. p-value: joint p-value assessing significance mediator's indirect effect, calculated based corresponding statistical approach. tau: quantile level outcome (applicable using quantile mediation model).

title: High-dimensional Mediation Analysis — hima
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Note: In the following examples, M1, M2, and M3 are true mediators.  # Example 1 (continuous outcome - linear HIMA): head(ContinuousOutcome$PhenoData)  e1 <- hima(Outcome ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = ContinuousOutcome$PhenoData,   data.M = ContinuousOutcome$Mediator,   mediator.type = "gaussian",   penalty = "MCP", # Can be "DBlasso" for hima_dblasso   scale = FALSE ) # Disabled only for simulation data summary(e1)  # Efficient HIMA (only applicable to mediators and outcomes that are # both continuous and normally distributed.) e1e <- hima(Outcome ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = ContinuousOutcome$PhenoData,   data.M = ContinuousOutcome$Mediator,   mediator.type = "gaussian",   efficient = TRUE,   penalty = "MCP", # Efficient HIMA does not support DBlasso   scale = FALSE ) # Disabled only for simulation data summary(e1e)  # Example 2 (binary outcome - logistic HIMA): head(BinaryOutcome$PhenoData)  e2 <- hima(Disease ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = BinaryOutcome$PhenoData,   data.M = BinaryOutcome$Mediator,   mediator.type = "gaussian",   penalty = "MCP",   scale = FALSE ) # Disabled only for simulation data summary(e2)  # Example 3 (time-to-event outcome - survival HIMA): head(SurvivalData$PhenoData)  e3 <- hima(Surv(Time, Status) ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = SurvivalData$PhenoData,   data.M = SurvivalData$Mediator,   mediator.type = "gaussian",   penalty = "DBlasso",   scale = FALSE ) # Disabled only for simulation data summary(e3)  # Example 4 (compositional data as mediator, e.g., microbiome): head(MicrobiomeData$PhenoData)  e4 <- hima(Outcome ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = MicrobiomeData$PhenoData,   data.M = MicrobiomeData$Mediator,   mediator.type = "compositional",   penalty = "DBlasso" ) # Scaling is always enabled internally for hima_microbiome summary(e4)  #' # Example 5 (quantile mediation anlaysis - quantile HIMA): head(QuantileData$PhenoData)  # Note that the function will prompt input for quantile level. e5 <- hima(Outcome ~ Treatment + Sex + Age,   data.pheno = QuantileData$PhenoData,   data.M = QuantileData$Mediator,   mediator.type = "gaussian",   quantile = TRUE,   penalty = "MCP", # Quantile HIMA does not support DBlasso   scale = FALSE, # Disabled only for simulation data   tau = c(0.3, 0.5, 0.7) ) # Specify multiple quantile level summary(e5) } # }

title: Classic high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_classic
text: hima_classic used estimate test classic high-dimensional mediation effects (linear & logistic regression).

title: Classic high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_classic
code: hima_classic(   X,   M,   Y,   COV.XM = NULL,   COV.MY = COV.XM,   Y.type = c("continuous", "binary"),   M.type = c("gaussian", "negbin"),   penalty = c("MCP", "SCAD", "lasso"),   topN = NULL,   parallel = FALSE,   ncore = 1,   scale = TRUE,   Bonfcut = 0.05,   verbose = FALSE,   ... )

title: Classic high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_classic
text: X vector exposure. use data.frame matrix. M data.frame matrix high-dimensional mediators. Rows represent samples, columns represent variables. Y vector outcome. Can either continuous binary (0-1). use data.frame matrix. COV.XM data.frame matrix covariates dataset testing association M ~ X. Covariates specified participate penalization. Default = NULL. covariates contain mixed data types, please make sure categorical variables properly formatted factor type. COV.data.frame matrix covariates dataset testing association Y ~ M. Covariates specified participate penalization. specified, set covariates M ~ X applied (.e., COV.XM. Using different sets covariates allowed needs handled carefully. Y.type data type outcome (Y). Either 'continuous' (default) 'binary'. M.type data type mediator (M). Either 'gaussian' (default) 'negbin' (.e., negative binomial). penalty penalty applied model. Either 'MCP' (default), 'SCAD', 'lasso'. topN integer specifying number top markers sure independent screening. Default = NULL. NULL, topN either ceiling(n/log(n)) continuous outcome, ceiling(n/(2*log(n))) binary outcome, n sample size. sample size greater topN (pre-specified calculated), mediators included test (.e. low-dimensional scenario). parallel logical. Enable parallel computing feature? Default = FALSE. ncore number cores run parallel computing Valid parallel = TRUE. default max number cores available machine utilized. scale logical. function scale data? Default = TRUE. Bonfcut Bonferroni-corrected p value cutoff applied select significant mediators. Default = 0.05. verbose logical. function verbose? Default = FALSE. ... arguments passed ncvreg.

title: Classic high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_classic
text: data.frame containing mediation testing results selected mediators. Index: mediation name selected significant mediator. alpha_hat: coefficient estimates exposure (X) –> mediators (M) (adjusted covariates). beta_hat: coefficient estimates mediators (M) –> outcome (Y) (adjusted covariates exposure). IDE: mediation (indirect) effect, .e., alpha*beta. rimp: relative importance mediator. pmax: joint raw p-value selected significant mediator (based Bonferroni method).

title: Classic high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_classic
text: Zhang H, Zheng Y, Zhang Z, Gao T, Joyce B, Yoon G, Zhang W, Schwartz J, Just , Colicino E, Vokonas P, Zhao L, Lv J, Baccarelli , Hou L, Liu L. Estimating Testing High-dimensional Mediation Effects Epigenetic Studies. Bioinformatics. 2016. DOI: 10.1093/bioinformatics/btw351. PMID: 27357171; PMCID: PMC5048064

title: Classic high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_classic
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Note: In the following examples, M1, M2, and M3 are true mediators.  # When Y is continuous and normally distributed # Example 1 (continuous outcome): head(ContinuousOutcome$PhenoData)  hima.fit <- hima_classic(   X = ContinuousOutcome$PhenoData$Treatment,   Y = ContinuousOutcome$PhenoData$Outcome,   M = ContinuousOutcome$Mediator,   COV.XM = ContinuousOutcome$PhenoData[, c("Sex", "Age")],   Y.type = "continuous",   scale = FALSE, # Disabled only for simulation data   verbose = TRUE ) hima.fit  # When Y is binary # Example 2 (binary outcome): head(BinaryOutcome$PhenoData)  hima.logistic.fit <- hima_classic(   X = BinaryOutcome$PhenoData$Treatment,   Y = BinaryOutcome$PhenoData$Disease,   M = BinaryOutcome$Mediator,   COV.XM = BinaryOutcome$PhenoData[, c("Sex", "Age")],   Y.type = "binary",   scale = FALSE, # Disabled only for simulation data   verbose = TRUE ) hima.logistic.fit } # }

title: High-dimensional mediation analysis with de-biased lasso penalty — hima_dblasso
text: X vector exposure. use data.frame matrix. M data.frame matrix high-dimensional mediators. Rows represent samples, columns represent variables. Y vector outcome. Can either continuous binary (0-1). use data.frame matrix. COV data.frame matrix covariates dataset testing association M ~ X Y ~ M. topN integer specifying number top markers sure independent screening. Default = NULL. NULL, topN ceiling(n/log(n)), n sample size. sample size greater topN (pre-specified calculated), mediators included test (.e. low-dimensional scenario). scale logical. function scale data? Default = TRUE. FDRcut HDMT pointwise FDR cutoff applied select significant mediators. Default = 0.05. verbose logical. function verbose? Default = FALSE.

title: High-dimensional mediation analysis with de-biased lasso penalty — hima_dblasso
text: data.frame containing mediation testing results significant mediators (FDR <FDRcut). Index: mediation name selected significant mediator. alpha_hat: coefficient estimates exposure (X) –> mediators (M) (adjusted covariates). alpha_se: standard error alpha. beta_hat: coefficient estimates mediators (M) –> outcome (Y) (adjusted covariates exposure). beta_se: standard error beta. IDE: mediation (indirect) effect, .e., alpha*beta. rimp: relative importance mediator. pmax: joint raw p-value selected significant mediator (based HDMT pointwise FDR method).

title: High-dimensional mediation analysis with de-biased lasso penalty — hima_dblasso
text: Perera C, Zhang H, Zheng Y, Hou L, Qu , Zheng C, Xie K, Liu L. HIMA2: high-dimensional mediation analysis application epigenome-wide DNA methylation data. BMC Bioinformatics. 2022. DOI: 10.1186/s12859-022-04748-1. PMID: 35879655; PMCID: PMC9310002

title: Efficient high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_efficient
text: hima_efficient used estimate test high-dimensional mediation effects using efficient algorithm. provides higher statistical power standard hima. Note: efficient HIMA applicable mediators outcomes continuous normally distributed.

title: Efficient high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_efficient
code: hima_efficient(   X,   M,   Y,   COV = NULL,   topN = NULL,   scale = TRUE,   FDRcut = 0.05,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Efficient high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_efficient
text: X vector exposure. use data.frame matrix. M data.frame matrix high-dimensional mediators. Rows represent samples, columns represent mediator variables. M continuous normally distributed. Y vector continuous outcome. use data.frame matrix. COV matrix adjusting covariates. Rows represent samples, columns represent variables. Can NULL. topN integer specifying number top markers sure independent screening. Default = NULL. NULL, topN 2*ceiling(n/log(n)), n sample size. sample size greater topN (pre-specified calculated), mediators included test (.e. low-dimensional scenario). scale logical. function scale data? Default = TRUE. FDRcut Benjamini-Hochberg FDR cutoff applied select significant mediators. Default = 0.05. verbose logical. function verbose? Default = FALSE.

title: Efficient high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_efficient
text: data.frame containing mediation testing results significant mediators (FDR <FDRcut). Index: mediation name selected significant mediator. alpha_hat: coefficient estimates exposure (X) –> mediators (M) (adjusted covariates). alpha_se: standard error alpha. beta_hat: coefficient estimates mediators (M) –> outcome (Y) (adjusted covariates exposure). beta_se: standard error beta. IDE: mediation (indirect) effect, .e., alpha*beta. rimp: relative importance mediator. pmax: joint raw p-value selected significant mediator (based divide-aggregate composite-null test [DACT] method).

title: Efficient high-dimensional mediation analysis — hima_efficient
text: Bai X, Zheng Y, Hou L, Zheng C, Liu L, Zhang H. Efficient Testing Procedure High-dimensional Mediators FDR Control. Statistics Biosciences. 2024. DOI: 10.1007/s12561-024-09447-4.

FDRcut Hommel FDR cutoff applied select significant mediators. Default = 0.05. verbose logical. function verbose? Default = FALSE.

title: High-dimensional mediation analysis for compositional microbiome data — hima_microbiome
text: data.frame containing mediation testing results significant mediators (FDR <FDRcut). Index: mediation name selected significant mediator. alpha_hat: coefficient estimates exposure (X) –> mediators (M) (adjusted covariates). alpha_se: standard error alpha. beta_hat: coefficient estimates mediators (M) –> outcome (Y) (adjusted covariates exposure). beta_se: standard error beta. IDE: mediation (indirect) effect, .e., alpha*beta. rimp: relative importance mediator. pmax: joint raw p-value selected significant mediator (based Hommel FDR method).

title: High-dimensional quantile mediation analysis — hima_quantile
code: hima_quantile(   X,   M,   Y,   COV = NULL,   penalty = c("MCP", "SCAD", "lasso"),   topN = NULL,   tau = 0.5,   scale = TRUE,   Bonfcut = 0.05,   verbose = FALSE,   ... )

title: High-dimensional quantile mediation analysis — hima_quantile
text: X vector exposure. use data.frame matrix. M data.frame matrix high-dimensional mediators. Rows represent samples, columns represent mediator variables. Y vector continuous outcome. use data.frame matrix. COV matrix adjusting covariates. Rows represent samples, columns represent variables. Can NULL. penalty penalty applied model (parameter passed function conquer.cv.reg package conquer. Either 'MCP' (default), 'SCAD', 'lasso'. topN integer specifying number top markers sure independent screening. Default = NULL. NULL, topN 2*ceiling(n/log(n)), n sample size. sample size greater topN (pre-specified calculated), mediators included test (.e. low-dimensional scenario). tau quantile level outcome. Default = 0.5. vector tau accepted. scale logical. function scale data? Default = TRUE. Bonfcut Bonferroni-corrected p value cutoff applied select significant mediators. Default = 0.05. verbose logical. function verbose? Default = FALSE. ... reserved passing parameter.

title: High-dimensional quantile mediation analysis — hima_quantile
text: data.frame containing mediation testing results selected mediators (Bonferroni-adjusted p value <Bonfcut). Index: mediation name selected significant mediator. alpha_hat: coefficient estimates exposure (X) –> mediators (M) (adjusted covariates). alpha_se: standard error alpha. beta_hat: coefficient estimates mediators (M) –> outcome (Y) (adjusted covariates exposure). beta_se: standard error beta. IDE: mediation (indirect) effect, .e., alpha*beta. rimp: relative importance mediator. pmax: joint raw p-value selected significant mediator (based Bonferroni method).

title: High-dimensional quantile mediation analysis — hima_quantile
text: Zhang H, Hong X, Zheng Y, Hou L, Zheng C, Wang X, Liu L. High-Dimensional Quantile Mediation Analysis Application Birth Cohort Study Mother–Newborn Pairs. Bioinformatics. 2024. DOI: 10.1093/bioinformatics/btae055. PMID: 38290773; PMCID: PMC10873903

title: HIMA 2.3.1 (2025-01-21)
text: Code optimization bug fixes. Function naming convention update. Allows contrast subset hima. Add vignette HIMA.

title: HIMA 2.3.0 (2024-10-28)
text: CRAN release: 2024-10-28 Coding optimization bug fixes. Renmae hima2 hima (hima2 retired 2025-11-1) improved parameter naming.

title: HIMA 2.2.2 (2024-08-23)
text: CRAN release: 2024-08-24 Add efficient HIMA function eHIMA. Optimization function hima2. Stablization estimates function qHIMA. improvements output presentation consistency.

title: HIMA 2.2.1 (2023-09-10)
text: CRAN release: 2023-09-10 Add quantile HIMA function qHIMA. Enable de-biased lasso penalty regular HIMA function hima2

title: HIMA 2.2.0 (2023-04-27)
text: CRAN release: 2023-04-27 Add wrapper function hima2 one-stop solution different HIMA analysis.

title: HIMA 2.0.1 (2022-07-17)
text: CRAN release: 2022-07-18 Rename family option hima function Y.family. Rename screen.family option hima function M.family Improve verbose messages.

title: HIMA 2.0.0 (2022-02-02)
text: CRAN release: 2022-02-03 Keep older version null_estimation package HDMT (< 1.0.4). Allows negative binomial regression funcion hima outcome binary. Add new function microHIMA handle compositional microbiome data.

title: HIMA 1.1.0 (2021-05-12)
text: CRAN release: 2021-05-15 Add new function survHIMA handle survival data.

title: HIMA 1.0.7 (2018-03-06)
text: CRAN release: 2018-03-06 Allow low-dimensional mediator selections.

title: HIMA 1.0.5 (2017-11-05)
text: CRAN release: 2017-11-08 Two different sets covariates allowed exposure outcome separately.

title: HIMA 1.0.4 (2017-04-08)
text: Benjamini-Hochberg FDR adjustment available.

title: HIMA 1.0.3 (2017-03-30)
text: Added error handler mediators selected penalized model. transparent information returned model fitting (verbose = TRUE).

title: HIMA 1.0.2 (2016-12-13)
text: Improvement: powerful model fit outcome variable binary. Generalized linear regression now allowed screening step.

title: HIMA 1.0.0 (2016-07-09)
text: Initial package submission GitHub
